I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the country programming meeting in November 2011, the Government of the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
policy and advisory technical assistance (TA)1 to support the Shanghai Environment and Energy 
Exchange (SEEE) in analyzing some key elements of its proposed emission trading system 
(ETS) and recommend policy measures for carbon market development.2 During the fact-finding 
mission  on  4–6  September  2012,  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  financial  plan,  and 
implementation arrangements of the TA were agreed with the SEEE. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Climate change caused by rising greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions has emerged as a 
major threat to sustainable development. Asia and the Pacific was the region most affected by 
climate  change-induced  natural  disasters  during  2000–2009,  accounting  for  85%  of  global 
fatalities associated with natural disasters. The negative impacts of climate change are widely 
expected to fall disproportionately on the vulnerable and on poor communities. Climate change 
has become one of the main drivers of massive migration and displacement in the region. 
Hence, mitigating climate change is an urgent task to support environmentally sustainable 
growth in the region. 
 
3.  The PRC is a significant contributor to climate change, responsible for more than 20% of 
global  emissions  in  2011  compared  with  less  than  11%  in  1990.  This  rapid  rise  in  GHG 
emissions is the result of energy-intensive growth. Recognizing the threat posed by rapidly 
increasing GHG emissions, the PRC reduced its energy intensity by 19.1% during 2006–2010.3 
The government also announced the reduction of its carbon intensity by 40%–45% in 2020 
compared with 2005. 4 The Twelfth Five-Year Plan (2011–2015) set a target to reduce carbon 
intensity  by  17%  and  energy  intensity  by  a  further  16%.  While  administrative  measures 
achieved significant results during the Eleventh Five-Year Plan (2006–2010), these need to be 
complemented  by  more  market-oriented  approaches  to  provide  economic  incentives  for 
emission reductions. One such approach is an ETS to enable the trading of emission reductions 
between enterprises that have obligations for emission reduction. Compared with other GHG 
emission control measures, ETSs offer greater flexibility to determine the price of carbon by 
using  market  measures.  They  allow  targeted  installations  to  meet  their  carbon  reduction 
obligations  by  purchasing  cost-effective  carbon  reduction  from  other  installations.  Many 
jurisdictions have implemented or plan to implement ETSs.5 Among these jurisdictions, the 
European  Union  ETS  is  widely  recognized  as  the  first  and  biggest  international  scheme, 
covering some 11,000 power stations and industrial plants in 30 countries. 
 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 July 2012. 
2  The TA is included as Study on Shanghai Carbon Finance Development in ADB. 2012. Country Operations 
Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2012–2014. Manila. 
3  Energy intensity is the amount of energy consumed per unit of gross domestic product (GDP). 
4  Carbon intensity is the amount of GHG emitted per unit of GDP. 
5  Jurisdictions that have ETS implementation in place include the European Union; New South Wales, Australia; 
Alberta, Canada; Tokyo, Japan; New Zealand; Norway; Switzerland; California, the United States; Regional 
Greenhouse Gas Initiative in several eastern states of the United States; United Kingdom Carbon Reduction 
Commitment Scheme; and Western Climate Initiative in the western states of the United States and some 
provinces of western Canada. The countries with plans to introduce a national ETS include Brazil, Japan, and the 
Republic of Korea.

2  
4.  The Government of the PRC recognized the benefits of an ETS, which it considers a 
cost-effective  way  to  balance  economic  growth  and  climate  change  challenges.  Given  the 
complexities and uncertain economic impacts of ETS, the government proposed piloting cap-
and-trade system for carbon dioxide (CO ) emissions in selected economic sectors and regions 
2
before  introducing  a  nationwide  ETS.  The  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission 
requested five cities with high carbon intensities—Beijing, Chongqing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, 
and Tianjin—along with the provinces of Guangdong and Hubei to set emissions control targets 
and submit proposals on pilot ETSs. 
 
5.  Shanghai is one of the PRC’s largest cities. It has a gross domestic product (GDP) of 
CNY1.92 trillion—about 4% of the national GDP—and a per capita GDP of CNY82,560 in 2011.6 
Shanghai emitted about 188 million tons of CO  and major sources are thermal power sector 
2
(37%), industry (30%), and transport (20%).7 The SEEE estimates that the total CO  emissions 
2
will  increase  to  330  million  tons  in  2020  based  on  expected  GDP  growth.  The  Shanghai 
Municipal Government (SMG) recognized the importance of reducing carbon intensity and has 
set the 12th plan targets for reducing carbon intensity by 19% and energy intensity by 18% by 
2015. The SMG considers the ETS a crucial market-based approach to achieve these targets. 
The SMG aims to build on its success in establishing the SEEE,8 which now handles about 70% 
of environmental commodities transactions in the PRC. An ETS is a natural fit for Shanghai’s 
highly  diversified  industry  and  fully  developed  commercial  sector,  which  provide  the  core 
competencies needed to plan, implement, and operate such a complex scheme. 
 
6.  The pilot Shanghai ETS will be an extension of the existing SEEE. The SMG envisages 
Shanghai as the future leader in the carbon market with a comprehensive market platform for 
environment and energy transactions both nationally and internationally. Driven by this vision, 
the Shanghai Municipal Finance Bureau, the Shanghai Development and Reform Commission, 
and SEEE requested ADB to provide TA to assist the SEEE in (i) assessing the impacts of an 
ETS  on  the  Shanghai  economy  and  key  sectors,  (ii)  recommending  sector-specific 
benchmarking methods and other system design elements of the ETS, 9 and (iii) identifying 
future innovative and tradable carbon finance products that can potentially be linked to the 
Shanghai ETS to ensure its sustainability and enhance the further development of the Shanghai 
carbon market.  
 
7.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  ADB’s  support  for  market-driven  emissions  reduction,  cost-
effective carbon finance, and carbon market development in developing member countries. The 
TA is a logical next step following ADB’s support to the Ministry of Environmental Protection to 
assist in the establishment of a national sulfur dioxide emissions trading system in the PRC.10 It

9  In ETS, a benchmark is used to identify a threshold for the level of free allocation of an individual installation. 
Usually, benchmarks are developed per product for each targeted sector. In the European Union ETS, a product 
benchmark is based on a value reflecting the average GHG performance of the 10% best performing installations 
in each sector. A sector-specific benchmarking method is often used for new entrants to the ETS to determine their 
free allocation as they do not have historical data on GHG performance.  
10 ADB. 2011. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for the Design of the National Sulfur Dioxide 
Emissions Trading System. Manila.

3
also complements ongoing ADB support for green finance development in Beijing11 and the 
development of an ETS in Tianjin.12 The TA will incorporate lessons learned from two other 
ongoing TAs in Beijing and Tianjin that are in early stage implementation through close and 
effective communications with SEEE. These three related interventions in Beijing, Tianjin, and 
Shanghai target vital yet different elements of the ETS. ADB support is needed in parallel as the 
three cities have major concentrations of emissions and different emissions mixes. Successful 
and early ETS application in these major PRC cities is crucial to accelerate a nationwide ETS 
implementation, which will lead to a more environmentally sustainable development in the PRC.  
 
8.  The TA is closely aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2020, which identifies climate change 
mitigation through energy efficiency improvement and mitigation of GHG emissions as a core 
area  of  operation. 13  The  PRC’s  country  partnership  strategy,  2011–2015,  promotes 
environmental sustainability as one of the two pillars of ADB assistance to the PRC.14 Improving 
energy intensity by using energy more efficiently and reducing carbon intensity have been 
identified as key interventions in this regard. Innovation and knowledge products to support 
policy reforms in order to establish an enabling environment for private sector development and 
clean energy investment are consistent with the PRC’s country partnership strategy. Piloting an 
ETS in one of the major cities of the PRC—the world’s largest GHG emitter—will contribute 
significantly to global public goods by mitigating climate change. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be a more environmentally sustainable development in Shanghai. The 
outcome will be an established carbon trading platform in Shanghai. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The  TA  is  designed  to  assist  the  SEEE  in  undertaking  the  pilot  Shanghai  ETS 
development  and  to  seek  opportunities  to  enhance  the  Shanghai  carbon  market.  The  TA 
comprises the outputs and associated key activities described in paras. 11–14. 
 
11.  Output  1:  Comprehensive  assessment  of  Shanghai  emission  trading  system 
impacts on targeted sectors and city economy. The TA will conduct an assessment of the 
likely economic impacts of a Shanghai ETS on the targeted sectors and city economy by 
developing a model with different emission cap scenarios. Based on the modeling results, the 
TA will recommend a cap and initial allocations for selected sectors. 
 
12.  Output  2:  A  policy  brief  on  sector-specific  benchmarking  methods  for  the 
Shanghai pilot emission trading system. The TA will conduct extensive research on various 
benchmarking methods used in other ETSs and propose sector-specific benchmarking methods 
that are suitable for the Shanghai pilot ETS. The initial benchmarking proposal will be shared

finalized and detailed sector-specific benchmarking methods prepared. 
 
13.  Output  3:  Policy  recommendations  on  carbon  finance  products  and  market 
development.  The  TA  will  conduct  detailed  research  on  existing  finance  products  and 
potentially tradable carbon finance products focusing on the role they play in carbon market 
development. This research will support the development of (i) a policy proposal on carbon 
finance rules for an ETS to ensure market liquidity, and (ii) policy recommendations on how 
carbon  finance  products  can  be  strengthened  for  further  carbon  market  development  in 
Shanghai. 
 
14.  Output 4: Policy notes on the Shanghai pilot emission trading system and the 
current  and  future  Shanghai  carbon  market.  Information  and  knowledge  sharing  is  an 
important  element  of  the  TA.  Two  policy  notes  will  be  prepared  and  disseminated  to 
stakeholders  and  other  external  audiences  to  share  the  (i)  experience  of  designing  and 
formulating the Shanghai pilot ETS, and (ii) knowledge gained from developing the Shanghai 
carbon market. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) for $427,692 and 
Climate Change Fund for $72,308.15 The government will provide counterpart support in the 
form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, and other in-kind contributions. 
The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The Shanghai Municipal Finance Bureau will be the executing agency for the TA. The 
SEEE will be the implementing agency. The TA will be carried out by a consulting firm (three 
international consultants for 12 person-months, and six national consultants for 30.5 person-
months)  with  expertise  in  ETS,  carbon  finance,  economic  modeling,  and  energy  and 
environmental policies. The consulting firm will be engaged using the quality- and cost-based 
selection method (with a quality–cost ratio of 80:20) in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The firm will be required to submit a 
simplified technical proposal covering all aspects of the terms of reference. 
 
17.  The  experts  required  to  undertake  the  activities  of  the  TA  include  (i)  an  economic 
modeling  expert  (international,  3.0  person-months);  (ii)  an  energy  economist  (national,  3.0 
person-months);  (iii)  an  emission  trading  system  benchmarking  expert  (international,  4.0 
person-months); (iv) an emission trading system benchmarking specialist (national, 6.0 person-
months); (v) a carbon market expert (international, 5.0 person-months); (vi) three carbon finance 
researchers (national, 6.5 person-months each); and (vii) an energy and environment policy 
researcher  (national,  2.0  person-months).  TA  funds  will  be  disbursed  in  line  with  ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 15 months from 30 October 2012 to 31 January 2014. 
The consultants will submit an inception report within 1 month after signing the consulting

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Advancing Shanghai Carbon Market 
through Emissions Trading Scheme, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The proposed policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) will be implemented over 15 
months from 30 October 2012 to 31 January 2014. As this TA project is directly linked to the 
Shanghai emission trading system (ETS) policy development for pilot testing, its main output will 
be the design of a few measures of the Shanghai ETS for government approval. The total 
consulting input is estimated at 42.5 person-months (12.0 person-months for international and 
30.5 person-months for national). 
A.  Consulting Services Requirements 
 
2.  Carbon market expert and team leader (international, 5.0 person-months, intermittent). 
The expert will have at least 10 years of experience and expertise in emissions trading, carbon 
financing  schemes,  carbon  finance  products,  carbon  market  development,  and  Clean 
Development Mechanism (CDM). The expert will have a master’s degree in environmental 
policy,  environmental  management,  environmental  economics,  or  finance.  Oral  and  written 
English proficiency is required. The expert will 
(i)  conduct detailed research on existing finance products, associated governance 
structure and regulations in the People’s Republic of China; 
(ii)  discuss how potential carbon finance products (e.g., carbon contracts, carbon 
bonds,  carbon  futures,  carbon  options,  carbon  index,  carbon  fund,  carbon 
insurance, CDM, and other carbon offset credits) will be played in the current 
governance structure of finance markets; 
(iii)  conduct  extensive  analysis  on  the  impacts  of  these carbon  products  on  the 
market liquidity of the Shanghai ETS and identify how different financial tools can 
support carbon market liquidity (for instance, West Climate Initiative-California is 
planning to have a special reserve to moderate price spikes that may occur 
during their ETS implementation); 
(iv)  prepare a proposal on how innovative carbon market rules can ensure market 
liquidity of the Shanghai pilot ETS; 
(v)  develop different carbon market scenarios for Shanghai (e.g., Shanghai ETS 
system in place alone, Shanghai ETS as a part of a national ETS, which might be 
or not be linking to other international carbon markets);  
(vi)  prepare  recommendations on how to innovate trading mechanisms to activate 
markets  of  carbon  products  in  Shanghai  using  different  scenarios  above, 
including risk control measures for carbon market and regulations for exchanges; 
(vii)  supervise and instruct the national carbon finance researchers; 
(viii)  work closely with the Asian Development Bank and the Shanghai Environment 
and Energy Exchange (SEEE) to discuss progress; 
(ix)  coordinate the activities of all other consultants; and 
(x)  take responsibility for all the activities and outputs from consultants. 
 
3.  Economic modeling expert (international, 3.0 person-months). The expert will have at 
least 10 years of experience and expertise in economics, econometrics, economic modeling, 
finance,  trading,  and  investment.  The  expert  will  have  a  master’s  degree  in  economics, 
environmental economics, or finance. Oral and written English proficiency is required. The 
expert will 
(i)  review emissions data, production data, and other economic and technology 
information on the targeted sectors;

(ii)  develop  a  modeling  approach  to  assess  the  likely  economic  impacts  of  the 
Shanghai ETS on the targeted sectors and run the model with various emissions 
cap scenarios; 
(iii)  develop a modeling approach to assess the likely economic impacts on the 
Shanghai economy and run the model with various emissions cap scenarios; 
(iv)  propose a cap and initial allocations for the targeted sectors based on the results 
of the economic assessment; and 
(v)  prepare the assessment report. 
 
4.  Energy economist (national, 3.0 person-months). The economist will have at least 10 
years  of  experience  and  expertise  in  energy  sector,  economics,  economic  modeling,  and 
economic  and  technology  assessment.  The  economist  will  have  a  master’s  degree  in 
economics,  environmental  economics,  or  finance.  Oral  and  written  English  proficiency  is 
required. The economist will 
(i)  review and collect additional emissions data and economic data on low-carbon 
technologies, and other information, if necessary, for the economic assessment 
of the targeted sectors; 
(ii)  assist  the  economic  modeling  expert  in  developing  a  modeling  approach  to 
assess the likely economic impacts of the Shanghai ETS on the targeted sectors 
and city economy; and 
(iii)  assist the economic modeling expert in proposing a cap and initial allocations for 
the targeted sectors based on the results of the economic assessment. 
 
5.  Emission trading system benchmarking expert (international, 4.0 person-months). 
The expert will have at least 10 years of experience and expertise in engineering, industrial 
benchmarking, carbon auditing, and emission trading benchmarking. The expert will have a 
master’s degree in engineering. Oral and written English proficiency is required. The expert will 
(i)  review existing studies on benchmarking conducted by the SEEE; 
(ii)  conduct extensive research on sector-specific benchmarking methods for the 
selected sectors applied in other ETSs and/or ETS-relevant schemes; 
(iii)  review and analyze emissions data, production data, and other economic and 
technical information relevant to ETS benchmarking; 
(iv)  prepare drafts on sector-specific benchmarking methods for selected sectors; 
and 
(v)  prepare and submit a policy brief on sector-specific benchmarking methods for 
the  Shanghai  pilot  ETS,  which  covers  the  targeted  sectors  including  power 
generation,  steel,  chemical,  cement,  equipment  manufacturing,  transport 
(tentative), and construction (tentative). 
 
6.  Emission  trading  system  benchmarking  specialist (national, 6.0 person-months). 
The specialist will have at least 10 years of experience and expertise in engineering, energy 
technology,  energy  auditing  or  carbon  auditing,  and  emission  trading  benchmarking.  The 
specialist will have a master’s degree in engineering. Oral and written English proficiency is 
required. The specialist will 
(i)  review existing studies on benchmarking conducted by the SEEE; 
(ii)  assist  detailed  research  on  sector-specific  benchmarking  methods  that  are 
applied in other ETSs and/or ETS-relevant schemes; 
(iii)  review and analyze the results of the sector assessment; and 
(iv)  assist  in  the  preparation  of  a  policy  brief  on  sector-specific  benchmarking 
methods for the targeted sectors under the Shanghai pilot ETS including power

12  Appendix 3 
 
generation,  steel,  chemical,  cement,  equipment  manufacturing,  transport 
(tentative), and construction (tentative). 
 
7.  Three  carbon  finance  researchers  (national,  6.5  person-months  each).  The 
researchers will have at least 10 years of experience and expertise in emissions trading, carbon 
financing schemes, finance products, carbon finance products, carbon market development, 
and CDM. Each researcher will have a master’s degree in environmental policy, environmental 
management, environmental economics, or finance. Oral and written English proficiency is 
required. The researchers will 
(i)  assist the carbon market expert in researching existing finance products; and 
potential carbon finance products that are innovative and tradable (e.g., carbon 
contracts,  carbon  bonds,  carbon  futures,  carbon  options,  carbon  insurance, 
CDM, and other offsets credits); 
(ii)  conduct  research  on  existing  and  potential  carbon  finance  policies  that  can 
enhance carbon market development in Shanghai; 
(iii)  assist  the  carbon  market  expert  in  analyzing  the  impacts  of  carbon  finance 
products on market liquidity of the Shanghai ETS and propose carbon finance 
rules for the ETS; and 
(iv)  assist the carbon market expert in preparing policy recommendations on carbon 
finance products and future carbon market development in Shanghai. 
 
8.  Energy and environment policy researcher (national, 2.0 person-months, intermittent). 
The researcher will have at least 5 years of experience and expertise in carbon finance policy, 
emissions trading, and carbon market policy, and a master’s degree in environment policy, 
energy  policy,  or  communication.  Oral  and  written  English  proficiency  is  required.  The 
researcher will prepare policy notes on the Shanghai pilot ETS, and the current and future 
Shanghai carbon market. The objective of this output is to share knowledge on the Shanghai 
ETS  development  and  further  carbon  market  development  with  stakeholders  and  other 
audiences that are interested in the Shanghai pilot ETS and the prospect of carbon market 
development in Shanghai.
